name: q16_9
probTex: Find the Laurent series of the function $f(z)=\frac{z-1}{(z-2)(z-3)}$ for the annulus $2<|z|<3$.
solnTex:
Recall that, for $|r|<1$,
\[\sum_{n=0}^\infty r^n= rac{1}{1-r}.\]
If $2<|z|$ then $\left| rac{2}{z}ight|<1$, so
\[\sum_{n=0}^\infty\left( rac{2}{z}ight)^n= rac{1}{1- rac{2}{z}}= rac{z}{z-2}.\]
If $|z|<3$ then $\left| rac{z}{3}ight|<1$, so
\[\sum_{n=0}^\infty\left( rac{z}{3}ight)^n= rac{1}{1- rac{z}{3}}= rac{-3}{z-3}.\]
Now
\[ rac{z-1}{(z-2)(z-3)}=(z-1) rac{1}{-3z} rac{-3z}{(z-2)(z-3)}= rac{z-1}{-3z}\left(\sum_{n=0}^\infty\left( rac{2}{z}ight)^night)\left(\sum_{n=0}^\infty\left( rac{z}{3}ight)^night).\]
Further simplification is possible, but unnecessary. We have a Laurent expansion which converges in the correct region.
Note that partial fractions would have ended with a sum instead of a product here.
